talked a little about this before, but root apy is high because the sum of the prices is high. we are getting the demand and speculation that we are looking for from the market, which pushes the prices above emissions. but the consequence of this is that root gets to sell these expensive tokens for a little more tao, which raises root apy

idk what the right term is, but you sort of create a vicious cycle when trying to fix the high root apy by lowering the tao weight

lower the tao weight -> alpha apy goes up. alpha apy goes up -> prices go up due to speculation and desire for high alpha apy. prices go up -> root apy goes up because now root is selling expensive tokens. root apy goes up -> users demand to lower the tao weight

basically, the more the prices stray from emissions, the higher the root apy will be. but the good news is that root apy trends lower and lower over time because it's based on the circulating alpha supply relative to root's power i.e. root stake * 0.18. the actual amount of alpha that root sells gets lower and lower. started at 0.41. currently under 0.2 for most subnets. will eventually be 0.1, 0.05 etc. 

we just have to be patient and let the alpha supplies grow

how would you disconnect root apy from the sum of the prices. root apy is based on the alpha_out that root is selling. the tokens are overvalued, so root is getting a higher amount of tao which boosts their apy

root apy drops when
1) the supply increases (root's proportion of the alpha_out that they can sell gets lower over time, primarily due to this)
2) the prices fall (root is selling less expensive tokens than before)
3) the amount of tao staked on root drops. this would lower root's power aka root stake * 0.18

the root apy drops over time no matter what. I guess the main idea people are concerned about is how long it should take. 

I personally view a high root apy as a side effect of the market speculation, which is what has pushed to sum to above 1.5. trading volume decreasing would signal lower participation, and root sell pressure would begin to have a stronger effect. root apy lowers in this scenario, but I don't think people wanna see this kind of behavior. like i said before, I think we just have to be patient and let the supply grow for each subnet. root prop will be something like 20% by the end of the year, and the discrepancy between root apy and alpha apy will become even larger by then

Collateral damage: the heart of the vibrant community that took more risk to support subnets is getting increasingly frustrated. Never good to lose early supporters. What is the root cause? Root APY? I am not sure if the reserves over injected metric is useful. at least not in the long-term. tao injected remains at 7200 per day. but you have a variable amount of tao coming in and out of the pools from participants. over time, wouldn't the injected always outpace the reserves? because people need to sell to cover expenses, and they might reinvest a portion of it, but not all. and I think there is a correlation between positive reserve over injected ratio and the sum of the prices. when the sum gets too high, a_in per block begins to get very low, and liquidity becomes an issue. the market would naturally bring the prices down to a healthier level

I don't think there is anything wrong with people wanting to stake on root. dTAO was always meant to be a gradual progression from the old system to the new. we have the root network so that early participants don't get all of the alpha inflation. I have held 100% of alpha since day 3 of dTAO, and it would have benefitted me enormously if root proportion dropped as quickly as it did on testnet. but I recognize that this wouldn't be fair, and that we have to give the system time to grow

if you think about all of this, the real culprit is the fact that the alpha supply can only grow so quickly. capped at 14.4k alpha per day. even if we got an "optimal" rate of participation, root apy would be inflated. because in a perfect scenario with proper participation and speculation, the sum would still be over one. it would probably look the way it does now lol

We could indeed wait, but another way to look at it is to address the demand side. Even when I speak to people who are supposed to know (such as the CEO of a renowned crypto company last week) they have never heard of Bittensor. However, once I explain it in simple English, they all show strong interest. Now, many give up when they try to understand after a quick search. Bittensor faces a top-of-the-funnel challenge (awareness and consideration), rather than a bottom-of-the-funnel issue (people are hooked once they understand). What is the first thing people look at? The website can be a good starting point and the current one is a bit embarrassing. One idea: In addition to the OTF (which guarantees the stability and robustness of the chain), why not create a second entity focused on marketing the ecosystem? This could be funded collaboratively by interested SNs, or more broadly using a portion of daily emissions, or other means. Put differently, it could be a decentralized cost center responsible for creating things like a great-looking website with landing pages for each subnet. It could also include features such as an RSS feed for the most relevant X-tweets (like a CNN banner), a voice-controlled 3-D avatar to help answer questions, and so on. This marketing foundation could also fund lobbying, media coverage, social media channels, and more. If structured as a subnet, it could incentivize miners to perform SEO on behalf of the chain

Please understand that the purpose of this Discord is not to support people who are using Bittensor as an investment opportunity.  It's for general network development, and for the most part, the priority of the developers is on making a robust ecosystem that supports the goal of Bittensor (first-class AI, developed through incentivized competition).

If you would like to get into more technical discussions about development that either helps or hinders people who are approaching Bittensor as an investment opportunity, the dTAO Discord is the better place to be: https://discord.gg/zT9hd3WAmG (the link is also in the #❓・faq channel if you want to confirm it).  While people here are going to be discussing further development of the network, it's not going to be possible to discuss this here with the focus on making things better for investors or encouraging people who are looking to invest.  So if that's your focus, check out the dTAO Discord, as there are a lot of very quite technical people who are probably already discussing development of the network with this focus there. : )

There's also the Developer-centric Church of Rao (here: https://discord.gg/gavmT4R8sB) and of course the Community Discord (here: https://discord.gg/vvUydTV85t) though I think that if you're wanting to talk about Dynamic TAO development that supports investors (rather than miners/validators/subnet owners), the dTAO Discord and Church of Rao are probably better places for it. : )

And this is why I'm pointing you to other places (especially the dTAO Discord).

In Bittensor -- with respect to your "standard" blockchain project -- tokens are not tokens (they're not independently tradeable, for example) and staking is not staking (a form of yield generation).

Staking on Bittensor is primarily designed as a governance mechanism, which is different from most places, and why people who are looking at Bittensor as an investment, but who are not familiar with how it works, get into trouble when trying to use staking to a subnet as an investment.

That's not the primary purpose of it, no.  Can it happen?  Sure.  Does the OTF want to prevent people from being utterly destroyed?  Yes, to a point, but they probably aren't going to prioritize changing Bittensor so that it becomes a "safe" investment vehicle.  As I mentioned before, and as Striker is saying, that's not its primary purpose.

Hello everyone,

Can you please clarify me some bonds questions

1 - I saw that **WeightsRateLimit** refers to how often a validator can set weights (explanation from Doc). 
But does it mean how often validator can send the *weights vector* to the blockchain to recalculate bonds? 🤞 

2 - And if WeightsRateLimit = 100 (from Doc), does that mean that validator's bonds are updated no more than once every 100 blocks?

Bonus Question:
3 - If yes — are bonds updated gradually through EMA bonds, or do validators update weights freely within the epoch and the EMA formula only compares weights between two epochs?
*(In the documentation it says that EMA bonds are the difference between weights across two epochs.)*

1. Close. Yes, this is the minimum limit in blocks at which validators can send updated weight vectors to the chain. In practise bonds are calculated during the epoch, and the most recent weight vectors submitted at the time of epoch are used to calculate bonds.

2. Epochs run at 361 block intervals and bonds are updated then. 

3. EMA is between epochs yes

if you're unstaking from a subnet, then take the alpha amount and multiply by 1 billion

if you're unstaking from root, then take the tao amount and multiply by 1 billion

if you're moving stake (moveStake) from one subnet to another, use the origin subnet alpha amount. e.g. moving 10 billion alphaRAO (10 alpha tokens) from subnet 1 to subnet 2

the system was always designed so that the prices closely reflected emissions aka sum is 1, emission % is 1

in the old systems, you would stop tao_in when the sum was > 1. now, you only change a_in whilst keeping the tao flowing.

in either case, you would still have the sum trend to 1. except now, it's the market (including root) that determines this (based on high or low market activity).

overvalued tokens falling back to their intrinsic value is more of a "suffering from success" problem if anything. as we noticed during the first week of dTAO, as the sum gets close to 1, the chain buy pressure has a stronger effect. so even if for whatever reason there were no trading activity, subnet participants wouldn't really be affected by this, as the chain would keep the prices afloat

the sum dropping signifies low trading volume, and root sell pressure has a stronger effect as a result. but as we noticed on testnet, the effect of root sell pressure gets smaller and smaller as root prop. decreases. meaning, you'd more easily be able to counteract this sell pressure if root participants begin moving stake to subnets. which is what will likely happen once there's several million alpha in the pool. easy to buy the tokens with low price impact
How root : alpha proportion determine? When will we reach 30 percent or 20 percent root proportion?

alpha proportion is the inverse of root proportion

root power = root stake * tao weight

root proportion = root power / (alpha circulating supply + root power)

example with chutes 
990,000 ⁄ (1,380,000 + 990,000) = 0.417722
so root prop is roughly 41.77%

for root prop to be 20% , the circulating supply would have to be 3,960,000 alpha. assuming root power stays the same (same amount of tao staked on root i.e. 5.5 million)

990,000 ⁄ (3,960,000 + 990,000) = 0.2
This is a good point to surface. Perhaps the charts that show root weight should also have a label like "Consensus strength" or something better. That way, folks will have a better understanding.

Having spoken to larger OG miners over the past 2 months who are dumping their alpha incentives I have discovered that they do not really care about emissions going down if they sell. The reality for them is that they have a sunk cost of operations into the subnet and this was calculated as a business profit against the emissions at the time of earning - the delta of waiting increases risk and time value of the alpha and erodes profit .  If there is no net-new capital coming into a subnet to buy miners emissions (earned to date) they do not want to be the last ones holding the bag. 

Additionally, for the larger mining groups there are many subnets that provide lots of opportunities to go after and they are not interested in keeping track of everything so its easier to lock in profit and de-risk their inability to track the intricacies of 120+ subnets. 

The reality is that miners are a profit driven business, not investment businesses - like in BTC mining they have real costs and overhead which must be serviced and they want to generate a profitable bottom line. Some miners  may decide to hold for an opportune moment to sell. But the vast majority will lock in a known profit based on the emissions/cost basis at the time of mining. If miners want to speculate they will hold a more liquid asset like TAO with mining becoming a way to accumulate more TAO for their business. 

This is not my opinion this is learnings as a subnet owner speaking directly to miners themselves.

Last note is that larger institutional miners are entering the space. These miners may have a better capital management strategy (i.e. not dumping all at once). However, they are also driven by profit as their north start not IRR (investment return). 

**In summary this is what real world miner behavior ends up being as a result - I wouldn't say root selling is the entire reason - there are justifiably reasonable business reasons which is the typcially the same as BTC mining:**

- Miners treat emissions as cash flow, not as long-term investments.
- Holding emissions increases risk and reduces profit due to **time value of money**.
- Without net-new capital buying emissions, miners prefer to sell quickly to avoid being left holding illiquid tokens.
- Real-world costs (infrastructure, energy, labor) make miners operate on strict profit margins.

Great proposal—I agree with everything you've written. However, for purely strategic reasons, I would suggest splitting the proposal into two parts. The first should focus solely on building consensus around the idea that the weight needs to be decreased, without committing to a specific scheme. The second can then introduce your specific solution.

The reason for this is that there's a growing number of people beginning to understand that reducing the weight is necessary in one way or another. Our friend @Spaceτime [τ, ∞] , for example, provided an excellent argument for why 0.18 shouldn’t be fixed indefinitely, even though he doesn’t fully agree with the exact structure of the proposed solution.

In other words, it will be much easier to achieve the overall goal if we approach it in two phases. Phase 1: get community consensus that a reduction is needed. Phase 2: open the discussion on what the best parameters and structure should be.

the best argument behind reducing the tao weight is that you lower the baseline root proportion, assuming a baseline amount of tao remains staked on root indefinitely.

let's assume 5 million tao

if we take the max alpha supply and calculate root proportion

`900,000 ⁄ (21,000,000 + 900,000) = 0.041096`

lowest possible root proportion is `4.1096%`

if we kept the tao weight static, then this is the lowest it will ever be. `4.1096% of the 41%` to nominators & validators. which out of the total alpha_out, it's `1.6849%`

halving the tao weight with each alpha halving means that lowest possible root proportion would be `2.0979% (of the 41% to valis)`, then `1.0601%`, then `0.5329%`, then `0.2671%` and so on    *edit - fixed the math. if you wanna do it yourself, take an example root power (900k alpha, based on 5 million tao on root), and max alpha supply of 21m.  and plug those numbers into root prop. formula. then after halving, halve the 900k, rinse and repeat


by the time the first alpha halving arrives, and assuming root power is still 900k alpha, then root proportion will be `7.8947% of the 41%`. or `3.2368% of alpha_out`. this is already extremely low, and it's why I don't think we'd technically have to change the tao weight over time. but I like the idea of changing it, because you'd actually halve highest possible root power with each alpha halving, and thus lower the min. root proportion. and therefore root divs would actually trend to zero, even if you still have millions of tao staked on root. hope all that makes sense. sorry if it's confusing lol

Yes, that's a very strong argument for why the weight shouldn't remain static. After all, it's much harder to argue against concrete numbers than just perceptions. That's exactly why I suggested to @davfields | ReadyAI [τ,ט]  that the proposal be split into two parts—it's far more effective to first build consensus around the need to decrease the weight.

Only after that battle is won should we start debating how quickly the reduction should happen.

in dtao with more and more subnets created and less tao on root, wont there eventually be a point where there isnt enough tao in existance to move prices much?

yeah, something like that. alpha prices stabilize over time because of the deep liquidity in the pools. millions of alpha paired alongside 10s of thousands, 100s of thousands, or even millions of tao, means that large buys and sells won't disrupt the ratio as much. and so price impact will be very low. there's still well over 10 million tao that will be emitted, and the vast majority of it will flow into the pools

another factor is root proportion. it decreases as the alpha supply increases, so the amount of a_out that root sells gets lower over time, and root apy falls. so that also makes it easier for the pools to maintain their price, with root sell pressure getting weaker

this is one reason why I think the sum will probably end up being somewhere between 1.2 and 1.5 long-term. intrinsic value from the chain plus speculation from the market, with root having less and less of an impact on the alpha prices, will always keep the sum above 1 to some degree

Hi everyone.

Was a slowing down new subnet registrations thought off?

Liquidity dilutes every time a new subnet becomes active, much of the liquidity moves to the newer prioritising for profit, while at the same time the sell pressure increases because new subnets are not as capitalised as older ones.

For these reasons, I think subnet registration should be enabled or paused depending of a certain TAO threshold of liquidity being present in subnets, alpha to TAO delta.

I reckon that a better solution should be envisioned and built that is not a complete lock out the new builders that want to bring value to the protocol.

Cheers everyone.

You might solve this with a type of contract known as a "deed of mutual wills" which concludes ownership at death. This agreement ensures that property is distributed according to agreed terms - the compounding issue in this instance then becomes who is the final authority on proclaiming "death" and what conditions might need to be met to for it to be declared, or what actions would invoke it
it might not be retroactively enforceable, unless parties consent to entering into such a contract, but it might be considered as an option on new registrations
and a separate solve considered for pre-existing subnets - making them a class of their own (which isn't especially elegant and perhaps undesirable)

well no. what I am describing is the tao and alpha flowing into the pool from the system i.e. tao_in and a_in

the subnet participants receive a_out

root receives a portion of the a_out sent to valis, depending on the root proportion. root prop has an inverse relationship with the alpha supply, so as the alpha issuance increases, root prop decreases. started at 100% of the 41% sent to valis, now under 40%. 

alpha yield is a bit tricky, because it can range anywhere from 50% to even 1000+%. because the yield is denominated in alpha. but the value of the alpha token varies. so for example, chutes might have an apy of 70%, and a new subnet might have an apy of 500%, but the tao value of the apy from chutes will be much higher since its token has more value

if the price goes up, the actual amount of alpha tokens you might receive could be the same, but the value of the tokens will be higher. vice versa

if more participants join, apy decreases, because yield is being more evenly distributed. but also, as root prop decreases, alpha apy increases (or in theory should at least stabilize), as the amount of a_out that root is selling continuously gets lower

you're looking at the stake to reserve ratio. in this case, chutes' ratio is much healthier, because in the event that a mass selloff happens, the pool can sustain it without disrupting the ratio too much. you have a healthier ratio when the price is closer to emissions

market cap is important. but tao liquidity is the most important indicator for subnet success & longevity imo. sometimes market cap can be misleading because you can easily inflate the price even though the alpha supply might be the same across different subnets

> So Root also adds sell pressure by inflating the amount of alpha tokens essentially increasing the supply which all else being equal causes the price to go down but as price goes below emissions root starts adding more alpha?

yeah, root is constantly adding more alpha to the pool alongside a_in from emissions. this is actually beneficial to the subnet pools, because you want as healthy of a distribution as possible between a_in and a_out. tao.app has the alpha distribution ratio for example and it's a good metric

as the price goes below emissions, root doesn't add any more alpha than what it was before. it's actually the chain that starts adding more. the closer the price is to emissions, the higher a_in is until it hits max a_in

```
# dTAO Emission Notes

tao_in = (EMA price / sum of EMA prices) * block emission
alpha_in = tao_in / price

- When price < tao_in:
    → alpha_in > max(a_in)
    → scale alpha_in down to max(a_in)

- When price > tao_in:
    → alpha_in < max(a_in)
    → use alpha_in as-is

- max(a_in) = block emission

- block emission:
    → starts at 1
    → decreases over time with each TAO halving: 0.5, 0.25, etc.

- As block emission decreases, tao_in and alpha_in both decrease proportionally
```

> So is it then literally impossible to figure out how much further a subnet could drop before the buy pressure begins?

Technically each subnet could drop to 0, or to just basically say there is no real floor for them. Even though there is the buying pressure on an individual basis, the EMAs were speed up so much that it only takes 1 day for the EMA price/emissions to catch up with the actual ALPHA price. So while the buy pressure will be there it will not last that long when looking at it individually. Instead the subnet would just be losing out on emissions if it's the only subnet.

The reason you would want to look at the sum, and why the sum is rather what is more indicative of an actual technical "floor" is because the way this individual buy pressure from the chain works, is that when the ALPHA price is smaller than TAO emissions, that's when it kicks in, that could be extrapolated to when the sum of ALPHA prices is smaller than sum of TAO emissions then buy pressure kicks in (no matter on what subnet, it just does in terms of the collective sum). While one subnet can just continue to drop in price/emissions, the sum can't effectively drop below the sum of emissions (which is 1 at the current moment) - it could but would need enough constant selling pressure.

EMA 
`priceEMA[now] = price[now] *(ratio) + priceEMA[now-1] * (1-ratio)`
where ratio is a number less than 1 and now is this snapshot

this smooths out the changes in price depending on the value used for ratio
